this is not the case from the experimental data (in which the

We explain this discrepancy as follows: given the 0, d
are occupied by only five electrons in a
high-spin state, there may be several nearly degenerate solu-
tions to the SchrÃ§dinger equation and the present DFT calcula-
tions have converged to one of them. To obtain a truly accu-
rate electronic description of the Co
be necessary to make use of more advanced computational
methods, such as multi-reference methods. Still, even with this
, the agreement between the DFT calcula-
tions and the experiment is very good for Co
To visualize real-space analogs of the electronic bands from
the periodic DFT calculations, we calculated maximally local-
ized Wannier functions centered on the Co atoms. The result-
ing MLWFs had clear connections to the d-orbital populations,
as well as the locations of the negative charge-depletion re-
gions and VSCCs around the Co ions. Given that all five spin-
up d-orbitals are occupied, they form a roughly spherical ED.
The two spin-down orbitals add to the ED in particular direc-
tions, as can be seen from a comparison between the spin-
Figure 5a depicts the negative charge-depletion points (red
pointing towards the directions of the VSCCs. Figure 5dâ€“h
show the five spin-up MLWFs centered on Co
there is a clear connection between the charge-depletion
points and the orientation of the spin-up MLWFs. In particular,
the two MLWFs in Figure 5dâ€“g, which have shapes that are
orbitals, have one of their lobes
pointing towards the charge-depletion point along one of the
O bonds, and the other lobe pointing towards
one of the charge-depletion points that does not lie along any
O bond. In fact, this latter type of charge depletion points
towards a small void in the crystal. The MLWFs for Co
We also consider the charge-depletion regions and MLWFs
gions to the different orientation at various Co
The two (011) and (110) faces of cobalt orthophosphate
ions. Figure 6a shows a side view of the
(011) face. The arrows indicate the two edge-sharing
atoms in the bulk; at the (011) face (top layer), the two
ions only share one ligand in the sub-face layer. The MLWF
from Figure 5 is shown superimposed on two of the face
ions. The blue lobes pointing out of the face are point-
ing along negative charge-depletion regions. Similarly, at the
(110) face (Figure 6b), the MLWF from Figure 5d have lobes
pointing out of the face, towards negative charge-depletion re-
gions. Considering cooperativity between two nearby Co ions
as for example, stabilizing low oxidation states
